Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Training Undergraduates in Electrochemical Technologies for Clean Fuels (Biofuels and Hydrogen) Production and Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Old Dominion University (ODU) engages undergraduate students traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields in hands-on research in the fields of electrochemical clean fuel production and applications, including solar fuel production, biofuels upgrading and production, and fuel cell materials and applications. The U.S. pioneered the development of these technologies, and continues to lead the way from laboratories to commercial markets. However there is a general lack of understanding and awareness of these technologies in the public and also among the stakeholders. This REU Site will help in educating and preparing undergraduate students in this area and play a role in the development of energy professionals for a sustainable society.

This REU Site offers opportunities for undergraduate students, working with faculty mentors and industry professionals, to engage in multidisciplinary electrochemical clean fuel research activities during a 10-week summer program. In addition to active energy research projects mentored by faculty from the College of Engineering, students will participate in research seminars, workshops on writing and communications training, field trips to industries related to clean energy, and career development activities. Recruitment of REU Site participants will target 12 collaborating institutions which include Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) and undergraduate institutions with limited STEM research activities.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

POR.DRECONTENT:
REU Site: Training Undergraduates in Electrochemical Technologies for Clean Fuels (Biofuels and Hydrogen) Production and Applications started on 9/102016and ended on 12/31/2019. A total of 35 students and 2 teachers participated in the REU, including 5 students who were funded by other sources.

Intellectual Merit: The REU Site program has resulted in 2 journal articles (1 published and 1 submitted) 1,2  and 7 conference papers and presentations (). 3 REUs received the best presentation award in 2017 WBHR-LSAMP Annual Summer Research Symposium on July 27, 2017 at Morgan State University. One REU received a full FASEB Mentored Poster/Platform Presenter Award (up to $1,850) to present her research findings at ABRCMS, Phoenix, Arizona, November 1-4, 2017. One REU was awarded a full travel Award from the American Society for Microbiology to present her research findings at the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS), Indianapolis, Indiana, November 14-17, 2018.  Two 2019 alumni will present their research outcomes in ABRCMS and AICHE conferences this fall, respectively.

1. Chen Li , Ashanti M. Sallee , Xiaoyu Zhang , and Sandeep Kumar. Electrochemical Hydrogenation of Acetone to Produce Isopropanol Using a Polymer Electrolyte Membrane Reactor. Energies, 2018, 1(10):2691

2. Beebe, Stephen J.; Bullock, Jimmie L.‡; Sandhaus, Shayna‡; Arca, Jessa Faye§; Celestine, Michael J.‡; Ludvig, Tekettay§; Foster, Sydney§; Beckford, Floyd A.; Tano, Criszcele‡; Tonsel-White, Elizabeth A.‡; Gurung, Raj K. ‡; Stankavich, Courtney E. §; Tse-Dinh, Yuk-Ching; Jarrett, William L; Holder, Alvin A. “Synthesis, characterisation, DNA binding, topoisomerase inhibition, and apoptosis induction studies of a novel cobalt(III) complex with a thiosemicarbazone ligand.” Submitted to Journal of Inorganic Biochemistry.

3. Dwayne Geter1, Anthony Porter, Jorge Lopez, Jinmyun Jo, Ayodeji Demuren, Xiaoyu Zhang (2017). LIGHT WEIGHT PEM FUEL CELL FOR UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLE. 2017 WBHR-LSAMP Annual Summer Research Symposium. Baltimore, MD

4. Jon-Thomas Smith, Can Zhou, Xiaoyu Zhang, Jinmyun Jo (2018). CREATING CATHODES FOR SOLID OXIDE PHOTOCHEMICAL CELLS. WBHR-LSAMP 2018 Annual Summer Research Symposium. Petersburg, VA

5. Efren Cervantes, Jai Sawyer, Xiaoyu Zhang, Jinmyun Jo (2018). CREATING POROUS PARTS WITH CERAMIC-BASED RESIN USING A SLA 3D-PRINTING. WBHR-LSAMP 2018 Annual Summer Research Symposium. Petersburg, VA.

6. Council on Undergraduate Research’s Research Experiences for Undergraduates Symposium, Alexandria, Virginia, October 22-23, 2017.  Title: “An in-depth study involving a tetranuclear cobalt(III) complex as a water oxidation catalyst.”  Authors: Abbygail J. Reid, Maurice S. Dilán-Hernández, Gyanendra Kharel, Raj K. Gurung, Michael J. Celestine, Donovan A. Dixon, and Alvin A. Holder.

7. Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students, Phoenix, Arizona, November 01-04, 2017.  Title: “A study involving a tetranuclear cobalt(III) complex as a water oxidation catalyst.”  Authors: Abbygail J. Reid, Maurice S. Dilán-Hernández, Gyanendra Kharel, Raj K. Gurung, Michael J. Celestine, Donovan A. Dixon, and Alvin A. Holder.

8. 255th ACS National Meeting & Exposition, March 18-22, 2018, New Orleans, Louisiana.  Abstract # ENFL 547. Title: “Clean fuel application using a tetranuclear cobalt(III) complex as a water oxidation catalyst.”  Authors: Abbygail J. Reid, Maurice S. Dilán-Hernández, Gyanendra Kharel, Raj K. Gurung, Michael J. Celestine, Alvin A. Holder, and Donovan A. Dixon.

9. Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students, Indianapolis, Indiana, November 14-17, 2018.  Title: “Synthesis, Characterization, and Catalytic Studies of Lignin Model Compounds with Cobalt(III) Cubane Complexes.”  Authors: Jennifer E. Mejia, Raj K. Gurung, Michael J. Celestine, and Alvin A. Holder.

Broder Impacts: We have successfully recruited a diverse group of undergraduates, with focus on those from underrepresented groups. Table 5 demonstrate the statistics of our REU participants. Among the participants, 20 students are underrepresented minorities (URM) and 17 are female students. We recruited 29 REUs from the intuitions with low-research activities. Overall, REUs came from 25 different universities across 13 states and U.S. territories. We had 58, 80, and 63 applications from 2017 to 2019, respectively. Upon 2019 summer, 3 REU alumni are pursing graduate degrees, including one student who is pursing Ph.D. at ODU.  6 REU alumni who recently graduated have jobs in STEM related companies, including Naval Air Systems, Norfolk Shipyard, Micron Technology, Registrar Corp., RagingWire Data Centers, and ANTARES Group Inc. We have been using LinkedIn to track and communicate with REU alumni. 

In summary, the REU program increased students’ motivation to pursue advanced degrees and careers in STEM. All believed that they learned a lot about the research they engaged in, and their motivation to pursue a master’s degree in STEM increased. 

 


Last Modified: 01/14/2020
Modified by: Xiaoyu Zhang
